title: Stress
description: Learning to cope with daily stress and develop healthy coping mechanisms.
welcomeMessage: Take control of your stress levels. Master practical techniques for managing daily pressures and building resilience.

cards.introduction: Sometimes the body signals before we realize we're experiencing stress. Let's start there.
questions: How do you feel stress in your body right now (location, level from 1 to 10)?
What happened shortly before these sensations appeared?
cards.recommendation: For a week, notice and record physical stress signals. Why: this helps track early markers of overload.

cards.introduction: Sleep suffers first. Stress rarely goes away if we don't rest.
questions: How often do you wake up at night or feel tired in the morning?
What thoughts or worries prevent you from relaxing before sleep?
cards.recommendation: Create a 'shutdown ritual': 30 minutes before sleep — no screens, list 3 good events of the day. Why: restores circadian rhythm and improves sleep quality.
cards.mechanism: Regulation of wake-sleep cycle reduces cortisol levels.

cards.introduction: You don't have to be productive 24/7. Even machines overheat.
questions: What expectations do you place on yourself throughout the day?
What in these expectations is unrealistic?
cards.recommendation: Choose 1 task per day that you consciously 'won't do'. Why: you learn to allow pauses and reality.

cards.introduction: Thoughts in stress are often fast, sharp, and accusatory. Time to slow them down.
questions: What thoughts most often appear to you during overload?
What would you say to a friend if they thought this about themselves?
cards.recommendation: Find 1 thought and 1 alternative view of it. Repeat this exercise 3 times per week. Why: you train self-support.

cards.introduction: Stress often turns the future into a catastrophe. But it's just a scenario.
questions: What negative prediction do you often replay in your head?
What's the probability it will come true? What alternatives exist?
cards.recommendation: Write down your fear, breaking it into 'real' and 'possible'. Why: this reduces automatic catastrophizing.

cards.introduction: When everything falls apart — it's important to understand what's really under control.
questions: What can't you change in your current situation?
What's in your sphere of influence?
cards.recommendation: Divide everything that worries you into 2 columns: 'can influence' and 'cannot'. Work only with the first. Why: this reduces anxious brain activity.
cards.mechanism: Localizing efforts in the control zone.

cards.introduction: Stress affects attention. We lose focus, and everything seems worse.
questions: When did you last notice you simply 'dropped out' of the process?
What happened 10-15 minutes before that?
cards.recommendation: Once a day, take a 3-minute pause observing your breathing. Why: this trains focus and stability.
cards.mechanism: Mindfulness reduces cortisol levels and switches from 'autopilot'.

questions: What little things irritate you especially strongly lately?
What might this be related to besides current events?
cards.recommendation: Arrange a 'day of silence' — turn off notifications and minimize external irritants. Why: minimizing stimuli reduces sensory overload.

cards.introduction: Your body is not an enemy. It knows how to release tension.
questions: What physical actions help you release stress (movement, breathing, water)?
When did you last use one of them?
cards.recommendation: Choose 1 method (e.g., 'square breathing' 4-4-4-4) and use it 2 times a day for 5 days. Why: you form self-regulation skills.
cards.mechanism: Influence on the sympathetic nervous system.

cards.introduction: You have the right to stop. Even for 15 minutes.
questions: What would you like to do right now if you had no obligations?
What prevents you from doing this, at least partially?
cards.recommendation: For a week, do a 15-minute 'reboot' during the day: silence, tea, window, walk. Why: returns contact with yourself and reduces emotional tension.
